Award.AbstractNarration:
This grant funds the REU site "Complexity Across Disciplines" at Boise State University, hosted in the Department of Mathematics. This site seeks to produce cohorts of young researchers whose work and vision transcend current boundaries between STEM disciplines. The research mentors will each engage a team of nationally recruited undergraduate students in a research project with strong interdisciplinary scope and based on finitary mathematical structures. The mathematical foundations for these projects include algebraic structures, combinatorial structures and game theory. Each of the cohorts of ten REU researchers will be thoroughly engaged in contemporary research problems with applications to cryptology, biology and several other fields of inquiry. The projects have deep connections with important open problems in mathematics, and could lead to discoveries of importance to the security of currently commercially used cryptosystems. The idea to examine certain genomic rearrangement processes from a game-theoretic point of view is new to the field, has inherent value as a mathematical exploration, and has the potential to clarify observed phenomena in natural rearrangement processes. The study of splitting systems could give new insights into mathematical tools for medical, chemical and electrical testing as well as error correction.

The nature of computing and complexity has expanded from the academic to the practical arena through great strides in scientific understanding of basic processes of life, the biggest transformation in information processing in history through invention of the internet, and automation of all basic tasks in our daily lives. The need to understand fundamental limitations on computing, thus on basic processes of life, daily living and information processing, has never been greater. The research projects featured at this site ultimately relate to the question of limitations on computing. The motivations for the offered projects arise from the quest for efficient search or sorting algorithms and for efficient information security tools. The research direction of this REU program and its projects are guided by experienced mentors that include an early career investigator, a female researcher and a senior scientist. Through its recruitment process this program brings undergraduate research experiences to students from institutions across the nation where such opportunities are limited. By involving the REU students in intellectual outreach activities targeting K-12 students through the REU site's partnership with the NASA funded Idaho Science and Aerospace Scholars, students from rural communities with limited opportunities have one-on-one exposure to highly motivated STEM students from across the nation. This outreach activity has the potential to transform the vision of the K-12 students about their own careers in a STEM field. The site offers, in collaboration with several other summer undergraduate research programs at Boise State University, a rich array of professional and interdisciplinary development events.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The REU Site Complexity across Disciplines (REU CAD) was funded by NSF grant DMS 1359425 fur Summers 2014, 2015 and 2016. The site received 1031 applications and hosted a total of 29 undergraduate students and two qualified undergraduate international students whose participation was funded by their home institutions During Summer 2017 the site hosted, under a no-cost extension, three undergraduate students. The participants were affiliated with 29 different institutions nationwide. While 30.26% of the applicants were female, 32.25% of the recruited cohort participating in REU CAD was female.

The site offered several in-house professional development events, as well as professional development events co-organized with the Summer Undergraduate Research Community at Boise State University, a consortium of several programs including this REU site. The in-house events included workshops on communicating mathematics to various audiences, including funding agencies. During this period of funding three of the site’s alumni were awarded the NSF Graduate Fellowship to support their subsequent graduate studies. The jointly organized events resulted in a diverse community of undergraduate researchers and faculty mentors. The site also hosted eleven speakers from Mathematics departments nationwide.

The site strongly promotes developing communication skills towards dissemination of its research projects and findings. In line with this effort, the site spearheaded founding the Idaho Conference on Undergraduate Research (ICUR). This conference is open for participation by undergraduate students from all institutions in all disciplines, and for attendance by the public. The site’s cohort of student researchers presented posters at this conference with special attention to presenting to a wide, diverse audience. The site also collaborated with three other REU sites at Boise State University in hosting the REU FORUM in STEM interdisciplinary seminar. At this venue, the REU fellows introduced their peers in STEM REUs from other disciplines to the site’s research projects. The culminating on-site event is the Summer Undergraduate Research Symposium in Mathematics. It is open to faculty and students in Mathematics, and to attendance by the public. Recognition of elevated communication skills came in the form of Mathematical Association of America Outstanding Presentation awards to four REU CAD posters presented at the annual Joint Mathematics Meetings in January 2016, January 2017 and January 2018.

The site’s public outreach activities under this grant included hosting cryptology workshops for the summer academy of the NASA funded Idaho Science and Aerospace Scholars Program for high schools in Idaho (Summer 2014-2016), and engaging students from the Ada County Boys and Girls club with hands-on activities related to the site’s research projects.

The site’s research program engaged participants in interdisciplinary mathematics-based research projects that advanced the frontiers of knowledge in fields related to information security and genome biology. Accomplishments include: Establishing a sharp bound on a game-theoretic result related to permutation sorting, discovery that one of the two postulated sorting operations acting in ciliate genome maintenance acts as a rescue operation for the other, less robust, postulated sorting operation at work, discovery of a trichotomous classification of two-rooted finite simple graphs, and explicit formulae enumerating the number of graphs on n vertices in each class, exploiting classical permutation factoring results to obtain a novel quantification of permutation sortability by context directed block interchanges, the NP-completeness of a decision problem based on a standard search strategy. In the Information security arena:  The Advanced Encryption Standard (AES) was adopted in 2001 by the U.S. National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST), AES and its components are used in many applications, including the design of other crypto-primitives, like for example hash functions. During this funding period research at REU CAD generalized the symmetric key cryptosystem AES from its classical form to a form functional over several other mathematical platforms, useful for future ciphers based on AES components. The hash function Grostl, among the top five finalists for the NIST competition for a new standard hash function, uses AES components in its design. Research on Grøstl not only generalized it to a broader mathematical platform, but also established a connection between the requirement of being collision free, with the significant body of work on the design of Latin squares. The site also made fundamental contributions to the study of efficient primality testing, a keystone in the design and deployment of secure information security tools. In particular, the site made fundamental contributions to the theory of pseudoprimes arising in the context of elliptic curves.
